An extremely grudging yes I do recommend it.  This game should be a single player RPG that is sold for $30 to $60 with no microtransactions and if it was it would be a wonderful 9/10 experience.   The gacha mechanics are an absolute blight on the game's industry, there is no excuse for them.  But, fair is fair.  You can experience the game's story without engaging with them with an insignificant amount of grinding.  I only recommend the game as a singleplayer experience where you enjoy the story and do not pay a dime for loot boxes.  I will detail how you do that below.   

So... the story is a bit weird.  The RPG where you play a normal campaign, make your choices, and experience different endings is a mode called the Spiral of Destinies.  This mode is clean of any gacha mechanics, it is just a normal RPG.  You unlock this mode by playing through the tutorial and unlocking a hub dimension called the Elysium.  Here you will earn a currency that buys you keys that let you play the Spiral of Destinies campaign.  That's already kind of weird and confusing but ok... at least its not hard to grind up some currency.   

The Elysium has other modes and it's own story.  You're given a few free characters to play through these with.  If you want other characters or want to equip your Elysium characters with shiny loot, that's where you need to start opening your wallet and doing random pulls.   You do not need to do this to experience the story, so I recommend you do not do that.   Just upgrade your free characters as much as you can with rewards from doing Elysium missions.  You'll get what you need to level up your characters enough to continue the Elysium story.  And while doing that you'll earn what you need to play Spiral of Destiny runs, where the real meat of the game is.  Let the rest of the gacha infested game sit in the shame corner.   

Sword of Convallaria as a single player RPG is great.  I really wish that I could just pay the devs for their hard work, but I will not have any part of gambling mechanics.  Enjoy it for what it has to offer.  There's a good game in here.  It's just got mud on its face.

TLDR; 
PROS: Graphics amazing, 
Free game and you get gacha currency for free by doing quests, 
Story is engaging, addicting and relaxing gameplay with endless content. 
CONS: It's mobile game so the UI doesn't work well with PC and no steam achievements booo 

The graphics are beautiful and lovely and one of the main reasons I decided to try out the game. I’ve never played a turn-based combat or gacha game as much as this one. They don’t spam you with “buy this, buy that” pop-ups like most mobile games. The option to purchase gacha currency/characters are there in the background if you want it, but it’s never in your face.

A huge plus: you can earn summon currency just by playing and completing quests. I found out it’s a mobile game, so the UI can be a bit tricky with a mouse, but it doesn’t really bother me since I’ve gotten used to it, and the menus are easy to understand.

The story is super engaging, has light humor, and the characters are all so likable and cute ^w^. As for the content and gameplay — it’s so good and feels almost endless from what I’ve played so far. It’s a relaxing and enjoyable game to keep on your phone and play when you want to unwind and spend some time grinding quests for new characters.

I had my eye on this game before it came out, played the demo, and did play a bit around release, and this game is actually really good for what it is, which is a gacha game. That said I haven't spent a cent yet nor have I felt like I had to. It really does scratch the tactics RPG itch, with some genuinely creative and engaging mechanics across various game modes and characters. That's one benefit of having a bunch of set characters as a gacha does instead of a job system; characters need to feel meaningfully different in how they play to justify taking up space in the character pool. Characters also have psuedo skill trees and you can nudge them towards certain playstyles that way, like making a spellcaster single target or AoE focused, or a bit of both as you unlock abilities with more levels.
The story is pretty solid, and there is a lot of it. I'm having a hard time even complaining about the "limitations" you have on play because using up one "Spiral of Destiny" key, the item you use to unlock a "run" of the campaign mode, took up hours of my time and you get two of them free per week and more from playing. There are branching story options that incentivize replaying this mode to see other possible endings to the plot. Another form of story progression that runs parallel to the Spiral of Destiny uses an energy system that will be immediately familiar to anyone who has played a mobile game, and that's eh, but with the time I have in my day and how many things there are in the game that don't use energy I don't really mind it much in the end.
I mainly redownloaded the game to check out the Dungeon Meshi collab and they did a really good job with it honestly; characters felt well represented and the gameplay took inspiration from the concepts in the series in a way I thought was charming and creative. Absolutely a little upset only Falin/Marcille/Senshi were playable though. Chilchuck I get because he can't fight but no Laios? Really hoping they do a follow up event because there's a lot of potential there. They did a fantastic job making the event accessible to new players as well as it had its own progression system that wasn't reliant on you already having maxed out characters to be effective.
Some mild criticisms are that the game technically has controller support but it's much easier to just use mouse and keyboard as it was designed for touch screen, the mouse is just easier. It has all the standard trappings of a modern gacha game and I hold the belief that "it's a gacha" is a valid enough reason to pass up on a game if that's not something you're cool with or you're the kind of person susceptible to the kinds of monetization patterns in that type of game.
I'm now currently around account level 40 in the game and I believe 60 is the max, we'll see if it hits a point where it feels like I've truly hit a wall, but so far I haven't. It just doesn't feel like spending is necessary, you get a lot of free stuff including legendary characters, and legendary gear especially they seem to give out like candy. The recommended levels for things seem pretty generously tuned, like they probably balance it around the starter/free characters they give you. Even things like a daily log in bonus or battlepass I just find myself thinking "I don't actually need that though." Character pulls have guarantees after a certain amount, saving up pulls seems pretty easy with events, the main thing I'd criticize is a lot of the FOMO stuff but that's also par for the course with anything live service.
Overall actually really good, great tactics gameplay, some good and interesting challenge levels, and for the 40+ hours I've gotten so far, absolutely free.
